metadata.title: Nonlinear bending of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with graphene platelets based upon nonlocal strain gradient theory

sections.text:
Fast improvements in technology causes to provide the ability to manipulate porous graded materials for using in directed design of micro/nano-structures. The prime objective of the current study is to anticipate the size-dependent nonlinear bending of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with graphene platelets, and subjected to the uniform distributed load together with an axial compressive load. Via the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity, two entirely different features of size effects are incorporated in the third-order shear deformable beam model. In addition to the uniform distribution of porosity, three different functionally graded porosity distributions along the thickness of micro/nano-beams are supposed in such a way that the relationship between coefficients related to the relative density and porosity is considered for an open-cell metal foam. On the basis of Hamilton's principle, the non-classical governing differential equations of motion are established. After that, the Galerkin method in conjunction with an improved perturbation technique is utilized to attain explicit analytical expressions for nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection paths of the functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with the graphene nanofillers. It is observed that the type of porosity dispersion pattern has no considerable influence on the significance of size effects. However, by approaching the axial compressive load to the critical buckling value, the significance of the both nonlocality and strain gradient size dependencies on the nonlinear bending behavior of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams increases, and this increment in the nonlocal small scale effect is more considerable than in the strain gradient one.
Keywords: Nanomechanics; Porous materials; Nanocomposites; Nonlinear bending; Size dependency.
* Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 21 66405844, Fax: +98 21 66419736. E-mail addresses: sahmani@aut.ac.ir (S. Sahmani), aghdam@aut.ac.ir (M.M. Aghdam), timon.rabczuk@uni-weimar.de (T. Rabczuk).

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As a high-surface-area catalytic material, metal foams with nanoporosity has been introduced by the rapid decomposition of energetic materials. This class of materials has a combination of properties that cannot be acquired via dense polymers, metals and ceramic foams. Pia and Delogu [1] discussed about the elastic deformation characteristics of nanoporous metal foams via a refined model. Park et al. [2] presented a novel strategy to combine conventional electroless plating and three-dimensional proximity-field nanopatterning of nanoporous metallic foams. Heydari et al. [3] proposed a simple method for high-performance supercapacitors by building pseudocapacitive CuS nanospheres with nanoporous structures. Li et al. [4] reported a simple solvothermal-assisted sulfuration of nickel foam having controllable nanoporosity as promising asymmetric supercapacitor electrodes.
In order to improve the stiffness of nanoporous metallic foam, carbon nanostructures are an excellent choice to utilize as reinforcements. In comparison with carbon nanotubes, graphene platelets has the capability to enhance bonding with matrix, which leads to more efficient load transfer and further improvement in strength of the reinforced material. Zegeye et al. [5] analyzed the mechanical properties of syntactic foams reinforced with graphene platelets. Liang et al. [6] investigated experimentally the tensile properties of polypropylene composites filled separately with three kinds of graphene platelets with different sizes. Yang et al. [7] studied the buckling and postbuckling behavior of multilayer composite beams reinforced with graphene platelets. Barati and Zenkour [8] examined the postbuckling behavior of porous beams reinforced with graphene platelets distributed uniformly and non-uniformly along beam thickness. Kitipornchai et al. [9] anticipated the free vibration and elastic buckling of functionally graded porous beam including graphene platelet reinforcements. Chen et al. [10] explored the nonlinear vibration and postbuckling responses of functionally graded porous beams reinforced with graphene platelets.
Through production of micro/nano-structures, novel physical properties as well as new promising applications could be obtained. Therefore, the accurate prediction of mechanical characteristics of micro/nano-structures is an area of concern. At micro/nano-scale, it has been indicated that the general mechanical responses of structures possess size dependency, so it is of importance to prognosticate correctly the small scale specifications of micro/nano-structures. Consequently, a variety of unconventional continuum elasticity theories has been developed and applied to capture properly the size-dependent demeanor of such nano-elements [11-29].
Recently, some investigations have been carried out bin which, nonlocal integral elasticity has been developed to indicate the approximation modeling of the nonlocal differential elasticity due to its some simplifications. For example, Zhu and Li [30,31] developed an integral form of the nonlocal elasticity theory in conjunction with consideration of strain gradients to study the mechanical behavior of nanorods. On the other hand, revealed from reviewing the historical background, it is common that the small scale effect in type of the stress nonlocality results in softening-stiffness influence, while the
strain gradient size dependency leads to a hardening-stiffness effect. In other words, no one of these unconventional continuum theories could perfectly cover the small scale features at nanoscale. As a consequence, Lim et al. [32] proposed a new size-dependent elasticity theory namely as nonlocal strain gradient theory which includes the both softening and stiffening influences to describe the size dependency in a more accurate way. After that, a few studies have been performed on the basis of nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. Li et al. [33] presented an analytical model based on the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory to analyze the flexural wave propagation in functionally graded nanobeams. Also, Li and Hu [34,35] predicted the nonlinear bending and free vibration as well as postbuckling behavior of functionally graded nanobeams based on the nonlocal strain gradient Euler-Bernoulli and Timoshenko beam models. Simsek [36] used the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity to develop a size-dependent Euler-Bernoulli beam model for nonlinear free vibrations of functionally graded nanobeams. Yang et al. [37] incorporated the coupling influences of the nonlocal stress and strain gradients on the dynamic pull-in instability of nanoactuators. Li et al. [38] developed a nonlocal strain gradient Timoshenko beam model for free vibration analysis of functionally graded nanobeams. Ebrahimi et al. [39] developed a nonlocal strain gradient beam model to investigate the wave propagation in temperature-dependent inhomogeneous nanoplates. Tang et al. [40] studied the viscoelastic wave propagation in the viscoelastic single-walled carbon nanotubes on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory. Li et al. [41] proposed a size-dependent inhomogeneous beam model based upon the theory of nonlocal strain gradient elasticity for linear bending, buckling and vibration of axially functionally graded nanobeams. Sahmani and Aghdam [42,43] predicted the size-dependent nonlinear instability of multilayer functionally graded nanoshells under axial compression and hydrostatic pressure using nonlocal strain gradient shell model. Xu et al. [44] explored the bending and buckling characteristics of nonlocal strain gradient elastic nanobeams. Lu et al. [45,46] developed higher-order beam models based upon the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity to explore the size-dependent mechanical behavior of nanobeams. Sahmani and Aghdam [47] constructed a refined shear deformable beam model based upon the theory of nonlocal strain gradient elasticity for the nonlinear bending characteristics of micro/nano-beams made of nanoporous biomaterials. They also employed the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity for postbuckling analysis of smart magneto-electro-elastic composite nanoshells [48]. Li et al. [49] implemented the nonlocal strain gradient theory in the Euler-Bernoulli beam theory to analyze the nonlinear free vibrations of porous nanobeams with initial geometric curvature.
The aim of the current study is to utilize the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory within the framework of the third-order shear deformation beam theory to analyze the size-dependent nonlinear bending behavior of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with graphene platelets, and subjected to the uniform distributed load together with an axial compressive load. With the aid of the Galerkin technique and an improved perturbation method, the size-dependent load-deflection
response is predicted via an explicit analytical expression corresponding to different patterns of the porosity dispersion.

sections.heading: 3. Nonlocal strain gradient third-order shear deformable beam model
sections.text:
In accordance with the third-order shear deformation beam theory, the transverse shear strain is distributed parabolic across the beam thickness. As a result, in comparison with the Euler-Bernoulli beam theory, it has the advantage to take the influence of transverse shear deformation into account. Moreover, compared to the Timoshenko beam theory, it has the capability to consider the transverse
shear deformation with the same number of independent variables, but without any need to the shear correction factor. Within the framework of the third-order shear deformation beam theory, the displacement field can be introduced as follows ab c, , d = a c, d + e c, d − 4 H3ℎG 4e c, d + fg c, d fc ? ah c, , d = 0 10 ai c, , d = g c, d in which a and g in order are the displacement components of the porous micro/nano-beam along xand z-axis. Also, e denotes the rotation of the cross section at neutral plane normal about y-axis. Consequently, the non-zero strain components can be written as jbb = jbb + *kbb + Gkbb G . = fafc + 12 4fgfc?G + fefc − 4 H3ℎG Mfefc + fGgfcGN 11l mbi = mbi + Gkbi G = e + fgfc − 4 GℎG 4e + fgfc? 11 where jbb , mbi stand for the mid-plane strain components, kbb is the first-order curvature component, and kbb G , kbi G are the higher-order curvature components. In order to capture the both hardening-stiffness and softening-stiffness small scale effects simultaneously, Lim et al. [32] developed a new unconventional continuum theory namely as nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory including the coupling feature of the nonlocal and strain gradient size
effects. Therefore, the total nonlocal strain gradient stress tensor n for a beam-type structure can be defined in the following form [32]

sections.heading: 4. Analytical solution methodology for asymptotic solutions
sections.text:

sections.heading: 5. Numerical results and discussion
sections.text:
In this section, selected numerical results are presented to show the size-dependent nonlinear bending behavior of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beam reinforced with graphene platelets with different porosity dispersion patterns. It is assumed that the matrix material is made of titanium with = 116 ®l, = 0.33, and = 4506 ÀÁ/´H [58]. Also, for the graphene platelet nanofillers, it is supposed that ;<8 = 1.01 Â®l, ;<8 = 0.186, ;<8 = 1062.5 ÀÁ/´H, ℎ;<8 = 0.3 Ã´, ;<8 = 5 Ã´, and ;<8 = 2.5 Ã´. Additionally, for the geometric parameters of the micro/nanobeam, it is supposed that ℎ = = 20 Ã´ and = 20ℎ. At first, the validity and accuracy of the presented solving process are checked. For this purpose, by ignoring the nonlinear and strain gradient terms, the nonlocal maximum deflection of a simplysupported isotropic nanobeam subjected to uniform distributed load is calculated for various values of nonlocal parameter and then they are compared with those reported by Ghannadpour et al. [59] using Ritz method. According to Table 1, it is seen that a very good agreement can be found which confirms the accuracy of the current solution methodology.
In Figures 2 and 3, the dimensionless nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection response relevant to the nonlinear bending of a porous micro/nano-beam with uniform dispersion of porosity (Pattern A) reinforced with graphene platelets is illustrated corresponding to different nonlocal parameters and
strain gradient parameters, respectively, and subjected to ® = ®ÄÅ /3 and ® = ®ÄÅ /2 axial compressions. It is observed that the nonlocal size effect causes to decrease the stiffness of micro/nano-beam as at a specific value of the distributed load, more deflection is induced in the porous micro/nano-beam. However, by taking the strain gradient size dependency into account, opposite observation is found and it enhances the stiffness of micro/nano-beam which leads to less deflection for a specific distributed load. Moreover, it can be seen that by increasing the value of applied axial compression at the movable ends of the porous micro/nano-beam, the gap between sizedependent load-deflection curves increases. This matter is more significant for the nonlocality in comparison with the strain gradient size dependency.
Figure 4 depicts the influence of the porosity coefficient on the dimensionless nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams with various porosity dispersion patterns. It is obvious that for higher value of the porosity coefficient, the stiffness of the porous micro/nano-beam reduces as at a specific value of the distributed load, more deflection is induced in the porous micro/nano-beam. Furthermore, it is found that among different patterns of porosity dispersion, the porosity coefficient has the maximum and minimum influences corresponding to Pattern D and Pattern C, respectively.
In Tables 2 and 3, the dimensionless size-dependent distributed loads associated with various axial compressive loads and maximum deflection of porous micro/nano-beams are given for different nonlocal and strain gradient parameters, respectively. The percentages presented in parentheses indicate the amount of the reduction or increment due to the size effect in comparison with the classical counterparts. It is indicated that the strain gradient size effect on the nonlinear bending characteristics of porous micro/nano-beams is more significant than that of nonlocality for all types of dispersion pattern of the porosity. Moreover, it can be seen that the value of porosity coefficient as well as the type of porosity dispersion pattern has no considerable influence on the significance of size effects. However, by approaching the axial compressive load to the critical buckling value, the significance of the both nonlocality and strain gradient size dependencies on the nonlinear bending behavior of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams increases, and this increment in the nonlocal small scale effect is more considerable than in the strain gradient one.
In Figure 5, the influence of the porosity dispersion pattern on the dimensionless nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with graphene
platelets is shown corresponding to ® = ®ÄÅ /3 and ® = ®ÄÅ /2 axial compressions. It is revealed that among different porosity dispersion patterns, the porous micro/nano-beams having Pattern C and Pattern D in order represent the maximum and minimum bending stiffness. Also, it is found that by increasing the value of axial compressive load applied at the movable ends of the porous micro/nanobeams, the gap between load-deflection curves associated with the different patterns of porosity dispersion a bit reduces.
Figure 6 displays the dimensionless load-deflection response associated with the nonlinear bending of the uniform porous micro/nano-beam reinforced with graphene platelets corresponding to different volume fractions of the nanofillers and various small scale parameters. It is demonstrated that by increasing the volume fraction of the graphene platelet nanofillers, the nonlinear bending stiffness of porous micro/nano-beams enhances which leads to lower deflection for a specific distributed load. In addition, it can be observed that by taking the strain gradient size dependency into consideration, this influence of the nanofiller volume fraction is more prominent. However, the nonlocality plays an opposite role in this matter.

sections.heading: 6. Concluding remarks
sections.text:
The main objective of this study was to capture the both hardening-stiffness and softening-stiffness size effects on the nonlinear bending characteristics of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with graphene platelet nanofiilers which are subjected to uniform distributed load and axial compression, simultaneously. For this purpose, the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory was implemented to the third-order shear deformation beam theory. After that, with the aid of the Galerkin technique and an improved perturbation solving process, explicit analytical expression for the nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection paths of micro/nano-beams was constructed.
It was seen that by consideration the nonlocal size effect, at a specific value of the distributed load, more deflection is induced in the porous micro/nano-beam. However, by taking the strain gradient size dependency into account, opposite observation was found and it enhances the stiffness of micro/nano-beam which leads to less deflection for a specific distributed load. Also, it was displayed that among different patterns of porosity dispersion, the porosity coefficient has the maximum and minimum influences corresponding to Pattern D and Pattern C, respectively. Additionally, it was found that the strain gradient size effect on the nonlinear bending characteristics of porous micro/nano-beams is more significant than that of nonlocality for all types of dispersion pattern of the porosity. By approaching the axial compressive load to the critical buckling value, the significance of the both nonlocality and strain gradient size dependencies on the nonlinear bending behavior of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams increases, and this increment in the nonlocal small scale effect is more considerable than in the strain gradient one. Furthermore, it was indicated that among different porosity dispersion patterns, the porous micro/nano-beams having Pattern C and Pattern D in order represent the maximum and minimum bending stiffness. In addition, it was revealed that by taking the strain gradient size dependency into consideration, this influence of the nanofiller volume fraction is more prominent. However, the nonlocality plays an opposite role in this matter.

referenceMentions.context: Pia and Delogu [1] discussed about the elastic deformation characteristics of nanoporous metal foams via a refined model.
[2] presented a novel strategy to combine conventional electroless plating and three-dimensional proximity-field nanopatterning of nanoporous metallic foams.
[3] proposed a simple method for high-performance supercapacitors by building pseudocapacitive CuS nanospheres with nanoporous structures.
[4] reported a simple solvothermal-assisted sulfuration of nickel foam having controllable nanoporosity as promising asymmetric supercapacitor electrodes.
[5] analyzed the mechanical properties of syntactic foams reinforced with graphene platelets.
[6] investigated experimentally the tensile properties of polypropylene composites filled separately with three kinds of graphene platelets with different sizes.
[7] studied the buckling and postbuckling behavior of multilayer composite beams reinforced with graphene platelets.
Barati and Zenkour [8] examined the postbuckling behavior of porous beams reinforced with graphene platelets distributed uniformly and non-uniformly along beam thickness.
[9] anticipated the free vibration and elastic buckling of functionally graded porous beam including graphene platelet reinforcements.
[10] explored the nonlinear vibration and postbuckling responses of functionally graded porous beams reinforced with graphene platelets.

[32] proposed a new size-dependent elasticity theory namely as nonlocal strain gradient theory which includes the both softening and stiffening influences to describe the size dependency in a more accurate way.
[33] presented an analytical model based on the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory to analyze the flexural wave propagation in functionally graded nanobeams.

Also, Li and Hu [34,35] predicted the nonlinear bending and free vibration as well as postbuckling behavior of functionally graded nanobeams based on the nonlocal strain gradient Euler-Bernoulli and Timoshenko beam models.

Also, Li and Hu [34,35] predicted the nonlinear bending and free vibration as well as postbuckling behavior of functionally graded nanobeams based on the nonlocal strain gradient Euler-Bernoulli and Timoshenko beam models.
Simsek [36] used the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity to develop a size-dependent Euler-Bernoulli beam model for nonlinear free vibrations of functionally graded nanobeams.
[37] incorporated the coupling influences of the nonlocal stress and strain gradients on the dynamic pull-in instability of nanoactuators.
[38] developed a nonlocal strain gradient Timoshenko beam model for free vibration analysis of functionally graded nanobeams.
[39] developed a nonlocal strain gradient beam model to investigate the wave propagation in temperature-dependent inhomogeneous nanoplates.
[40] studied the viscoelastic wave propagation in the viscoelastic single-walled carbon nanotubes on the basis of the nonlocal strain gradient elasticity theory.

[41] proposed a size-dependent inhomogeneous beam model based upon the theory of nonlocal strain gradient elasticity for linear bending, buckling and vibration of axially functionally graded nanobeams.

Sahmani and Aghdam [42,43] predicted the size-dependent nonlinear instability of multilayer functionally graded nanoshells under axial compression and hydrostatic pressure using nonlocal strain gradient shell model.

[44] explored the bending and buckling characteristics of nonlocal strain gradient elastic nanobeams.

metadata.abstractText: Fast improvements in technology causes to provide the ability to manipulate porous graded materials for using in directed design of micro/nano-structures. The prime objective of the current study is to anticipate the size-dependent nonlinear bending of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with graphene platelets, and subjected to the uniform distributed load together with an axial compressive load. Via the nonlocal strain gradient theory of elasticity, two entirely different features of size effects are incorporated in the third-order shear deformable beam model. In addition to the uniform distribution of porosity, three different functionally graded porosity distributions along the thickness of micro/nano-beams are supposed in such a way that the relationship between coefficients related to the relative density and porosity is considered for an open-cell metal foam. On the basis of Hamilton's principle, the non-classical governing differential equations of motion are established. After that, the Galerkin method in conjunction with an improved perturbation technique is utilized to attain explicit analytical expressions for nonlocal strain gradient load-deflection paths of the functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams reinforced with the graphene nanofillers. It is observed that the type of porosity dispersion pattern has no considerable influence on the significance of size effects. However, by approaching the axial compressive load to the critical buckling value, the significance of the both nonlocality and strain gradient size dependencies on the nonlinear bending behavior of functionally graded porous micro/nano-beams increases, and this increment in the nonlocal small scale effect is more considerable than in the strain gradient one.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
